questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with major depressive disorder comes to the therapist for weekly psychotherapy. She got divorced 1 year ago. Last week, she spoke about her ex-husband's lack of advancement at work as he never asks, even after confronting him multiple times. Today, after asking how she’s doing, she replies, “If there's something you want to know, have the courage to ask me! I have no respect for those who don't speak their mind!” This behavior can be described as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transference Transference is a phenomenon in which a patient projects feelings (positive and/or negative) about important persons onto the clinician. This woman projects her frustrations about her ex-husband's timidity onto the therapist. Transference is not a type of defense mechanism.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Displacement (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual redirects impulses and emotions from a target that is perceived as threatening or unacceptable to another that is perceived as less threatening or more acceptable . Though this woman directs her frustrations about her ex-husband's timidity to the therapist, she has confronted her ex-husband in the past and is less likely to perceive him as a threatening or unacceptable target. Option: C. Passive aggression is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual demonstrates negative feelings in an indirect, non-confrontational manner. If this woman did not confront her ex-husband about his timidity and instead expressed her discontent through passive behaviors such as deliberate failure to contribute to shared responsibilities, she would exhibit this defense mechanism. Option: D. Projection is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual projects an unacceptable internal impulse onto an external source . If this woman were frustrated at her therapist and accused the therapist of being frustrated at her, she would exhibit this defense mechanism.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought for counseling because she was physically abused by his father. At the session’s end, the therapist, who lost her daughter in a car accident when she was 16 years old, refuses to let the patient take the bus back alone to her home. Instead, she offers to take her back, saying, “This way, I will rest assured that you have reached home safely”. The therapist's behavior can be best described as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Countertransference Countertransference is a phenomenon in which a therapist projects feelings about important persons in their own life onto the patient. This therapist has likely transferred her feelings toward her deceased son to the patient. Her breaking of neutrality in the absence of an immediate need (e.g., impending harm to the patient) and in order to alleviate her feelings of anxiety towards the patient's situation suggests countertransference.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Displacement is an immature defense mechanism that involves shifting negative feelings toward an event or person to a neutral, less threatening target. Option: B. Transference is a phenomenon in which a patient projects feelings (positive and/or negative) about important persons onto the clinician. Option: D. Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism in which an individual channels socially unacceptable desires into acceptable actions. An example of sublimation would be if the therapist sublimated jealousy toward her coworkers into performing better at work.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, comes to the Emergency Department with acute exacerbation of chronic pancreatitis. On probing he gives a history of chronic alcohol intake for the last 30 years. He has become fixated on which stage of psychosexual development according to Freud's theory ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral stage STAGES OF PSYCHOSEXUAL DEVELOPMENT STAGES AGE OF DEVELOPMENT OBJECTIVE DISORDERS ASSOCIATED ORAL STAGE 0-1.5 years Feeding & Mouthing Addiction, Schizophrenia, Dependent Personality Disorder ANAL STAGE 1.5-3 years Bowel Bladder Training Obsessive and Compulsive disorder PHALLIC STAGE 3-6 years Gender Identity Foundation Electra Complex in females (penis envy) Oedipus Complex in males (castration envy) LATENCY STAGE 5-6 to 11-13 years Consolidation of Gender & Sex role identity GENITAL STAGE After the onset of puberty Sexual orientation development

questions.text: What are the processes involved in the formation of dreams? Suppression Displacement Condensation Symbolization Select the correct answer from given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,3,4 Dreams are the economic expression of latent unconscious contents. The process of dream formation involves Symbolism Displacement Condensation Projection Secondary revision Symbolism : It is a complex process of indirect representation or substitution of the idea with a symbol that derives its secondary significance from the idea. A symbol is sensory and concrete in nature while the idea is relatively abstract and complex . Example: seeing anger as fire. Displacement : It is the mechanism of transfer of amounts of energy (cathexis) from the original object to a substitute which is relatively neutral and less invested with affective Energy. Example: In a dream, the mother may be represented visually by an unknown female figure (who has less emotional significance for the dreamer) Condensation : It is the mechanism by which several unconscious wishes , impulses, or attitudes can be combined into a single image in the manifest dream content. Example: In a child’s nightmare, an attacking monster may come to represent not only the dreamer’s father but may also represent some aspects of the mother and even, in addition, some of the child’s own primitive hostile impulses as well. Projection : This process allows dreamers to rid themselves of their own unacceptable wishes or impulses and experience them as emanating in the dream from other persons or independent sources. Example: The individual who has a strong repressed wish to be unfaithful to his wife may dream that his wife has been unfaithful to him. Secondary Revision : It is the final process that reorganizes the absurd, illogical, and bizarre aspects of the dream into a more logical and coherent form, particularly in the context of recounting the dream in a coherent narrative to someone else. Suppression is a defense mechanism and is not involved in the dream process . It is the conscious or semiconscious decision to postpone attention to a conscious impulse or conflict .

questions.text: A 25 years old female, brutally beaten by her husband is brought to the emergency department with multiple lacerations, bruises, and internal bleeding. However, the attending doctor shows no emotion. What kind of defense mechanism is shown here by the doctor?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isolation Isolation : The intrapsychic splitting or separation of effect from content resulting in repression of either idea or affect or the displacement of effect to a different or substitute content. Defense mechanisms are broadly classified into: Mature Defenses Immature Defenses Narcissistic-Psychotic Defenses Neurotic Defenses MATURE ● Altruism ● Anticipation ● Asceticism ● Humor ● Sublimation ● Suppression IMMATURE ● Acting out ● Blocking ● Hypochondriasis ● Introjection ● Passive-aggression ● Projection ● Schizoid fantasy ● Somatization Narcissistic-Psychotic ● Projection ● Denial ● Distortion Neurotic ● Controlling ● Displacement ● Dissociation ● Externalization ● Inhibition ● Intellectualization ● Isolation ● Rationalization ● Reaction formation ● Repression ● Sexualization

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A- Sublimation : The gratification of an impulse whose goal is retained but whose aim or object is changed from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one . Option B- Regression : A return to a previous stage of development or functioning to avoid the anxieties or hostilities involved in later stages. Option C- Displacement : Involves a purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses or affective investment from one object to another in the interest of solving a conflict.

questions.text: Match the defense mechanism to the respective diseases/ conditions. Select Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

Random:

Explanation for Points: Point 1- Undoing : It is seen in In this, a person performs a compulsive act even before the triggering act occurs. Other defense mechanisms in OCD include isolation; reaction formation. Example: A person with a cleanliness obsession may clean his hands even before his hands get dirty. Point 2- Denial is seen in Grief . In this, the person refuses to acknowledge what he sees or hears. Example: Mother denies that her baby is dead, even when she sees his dead body. Point 3- Regression is seen in Due to regressions a return to a previous stage of development or functioning is seen to avoid the anxieties or hostilities involved in later stages. Example: Thumb sucking (beyond the age of its normal occurrence) in a child when he is stressed. Point 4- Splitting means black-and-white thinking , this is seen in Borderline Personality Disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female spends hours cleaning her house to such an extent that she barely has any time to cook, wash clothes, or take care of her child. It is causing her a lot of distress. She has become fixated on which stage of psychosexual development?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anal stage The history implies that the patient is fixated on anal stage of psychosexual development. STAGES OF PSYCHOSEXUAL DEVELOPMENT STAGES AGE OF DEVELOPMENT OBJECTIVE DISORDERS ASSOCIATED ORAL STAGE 0-1.5 years Feeding & Mouthing Addiction, Schizophrenia, Dependent Personality Disorder ANAL STAGE 1.5-3 years Bowel Bladder Training Obsessive and Compulsive disorder PHALLIC STAGE 3-6 years Gender Identity Foundation Electra Complex in females (penis envy) Oedipus Complex in males (castration envy) LATENCY STAGE 5-6 to 11-13 years Consolidation of Gender & Sex role identity GENITAL STAGE After the onset of puberty Sexual orientation development

questions.text: A 45 years old male came to psychiatry OPD. He says my neighbor is planning to kill me even when evidence contrary to his belief was produced to him. He hears people talking about him even when he is alone. This has been going on for the last 8 months. Which of the following defense mechanism operates in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Projection Projection : On a nonpsychotic level, projection involves attributing one’s unacknowledged feelings to others ; it includes severe prejudice, rejection of intimacy through suspiciousness, hypervigilance to external danger, and injustice collecting. At higher levels of function, projection may take the form of misattributing or misinterpreting motives, attitudes, feelings, or intentions of others as in this case of schizophrenia, the patient believes his neighbor is planning to kill him.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option A: Isolation is the separation of effect from content resulting in the repression of either idea or affect. It is seen in OCD . Option B: Somatization is the defensive conversion of psychic derivatives into bodily symptoms. It is seen in depression . Option D: Undoing is seen in OCD . In this, a person performs a compulsive act even before triggering the action. Example: A person with a cleanliness obsession may clean his hands even before his hands get dirty.

questions.text: What are the correct name of the test and its basis?

options.label: A
options.text: Test: The Rorschach Inkblot Test, Basis: Cognitive Ability

options.label: B
options.text: Test: The Rorschach Inkblot Test, Basis: Free Association

options.label: C
options.text: Test: Thematic Apperception Test, Basis: Free Association

options.label: D
options.text: Test: Thematic Apperception Test, Basis: Cognitive Ability

questions.correct_answer: B. Test: The Rorschach Inkblot Test, Basis: Free Association
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Test: The Rorschach Inkblot Test, Basis: Free Association The Rorschach Inkblot Test is a projective tes t based on free association . The basic idea of this is when a person is shown an ambiguous, meaningless image (i.e., an inkblot; and not an image!) the mind will work hard at imposing meaning on the image. Based on the answers we can assess the thought process and internal feelings of the person.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Options C & D: Thematic Apperception Test is also a projective test with a semi-ambiguous image. In this test, a person is shown an image and asked to narrate the story based on it . Based on the story narrated we can Find out hidden motives, concerns, and how this person sees the world.
